title: The Velvet Guillotine
premise: In a perpetually rain-slicked 1947 Los Angeles, a washed-up private eye is hired to find a missing French perfume chemist—only to discover his client is the mastermind behind an impossible art heist already pulled off at the Louvre. Now, he's trapped between the ruthless French underground, the FBI, and a femme fatale who smells of a fragrance that can make people forget.
protagonist: Leo Vance, a former police detective with a heightened sense of smell (hyperosmia) and a guilt-ridden past, who now tracks missing persons by scent.
conflict: Vance must navigate a labyrinth of double-crosses to recover the stolen paintings before his client uses the amnesiac perfume to erase the entire heist from history, along with anyone who knows about it—including him.
setting: Post-WWII Los Angeles and flashbacks to occupied Paris; a world of smoky jazz clubs, pharmaceutical labs, and hidden art vaults.
tone: Claustrophobic and sensual, blending hard-boiled cynicism with the lingering, intoxicating threat of forgotten memories and inevitable betrayal.
